sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Here are our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Taking it up a notch. US President Biden will send missile system to Ukraine, whose forces struggle to stop Russian advance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Tightening its grip. Russia now controls most of the strategic Donbass city of Severodonetsk, as heavy street fighting continues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Russia issues one of its first convictions under its new fake news law, brought in after the invasion of Ukraine began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And 70 years and counting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: People in the UK are getting ready to celebrate the Queen's Platinum Jubilee, the longest reign ever of a British monarch.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the program. I'm Stefan Grobe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: U.S. President Joe Biden has announced plans to send medium-range rocket systems to Ukraine as defense forces struggle to withstand Russia's assault in Donbass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Top Ukrainian officials had long called on Washington to provide the high-tech weapons, which experts say will help bolster Ukraine's defensive capabilities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: But the U.S. had held back from sending weapons that could be used to target positions on Russian soil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The rocket systems form part of a wider military aid package worth over 655 million euro.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Speaking with NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg from Washington, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the weapons will help Ukraine to fend off Russian advances and keep a strong negotiating position. Just this morning, President Biden announced a significant new security assistance package to arm Ukraine with additional capabilities and advanced weaponry, precisely what they need to defend themselves against the ongoing Russian aggression.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That includes more advanced rocket systems so that they can strike key targets on the battlefield in Ukraine from longer distances.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This is a continuation of a strategy that began even before Russia's invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We moved quickly to send Ukraine significant amounts of weapons and ammunition so that they can repel Russia's aggression and in turn can be in the strongest possible position at any negotiating table that may emerge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Russia has strongly condemned Biden's decision to send the heavy weapons system to Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Speaking in Saudi Arabia, Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said Kyiv's demands for heavy weapons support were driving up tensions between Moscow and Washington.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What the Kyiv regime demands so categorically, in I would say a business-like manner from its Western patrons, already goes beyond all the limits of decency and diplomatic communication and secondly this is a direct provocation aimed at drawing the West into hostilities. Russian

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: forces have now seized most of Severodonetsk, the administrative capital of Luhansk according to Ukrainian officials Kiev says that although Ukrainian forces managed to repel several attacks the city is close to being overrun meanwhile president Volodymyr Zelensky said his military is losing up to 100 soldiers a day Zelensky also called the indiscriminate attacks of a chemical plant in several Donetsk as madness.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The situation in the Donbas direction is very difficult.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Severodonetsk, Lysychansk, Kurohov are now the epicenter of the confrontation, given the presence of large-scale chemical production in Severodonetsk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The Russian army strikes there, including blind air bombing, are just madness.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: In Mariupol, the ruined port city in Donbass, which is now under Russian control, more horrors are coming to light.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Earlier this week, around 200 dead bodies were found in the basement of a destroyed apartment building, according to Ukrainian authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Our international correspondent Annalise Borges spoke to the mayor of Mariupol, Vadim Sehyovych-Boychenko.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Annalise, and good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So, his city has seen some of the worst suffering of the three-month-old war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: What did he have to tell you?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Hi there, Stefan. Well, Vladimir Boishenko spoke about a city completely ravaged by war, where 50% of all buildings have been completely destroyed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He also spoke about crucial infrastructure badly damaged today in Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: There is no running water, no electricity, no gas, no internet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But Vadim Boishenko also said that the most painful aspect about what happened there is not that kind of physical damage, but the pain and the suffering of the people who are currently stuck there and now faced with an epidemic of cholera because of the hundreds of decaying bodies that have been abandoned in the streets and in buildings across the city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Take a listen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: People are exhausted by this hostile force which bombed our city for more than two months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They are morally destroyed inside.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Plus, there is no water and food.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They don't live but just survive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: They are upset and asking just for one thing, for us to create sustainable green corridors so that they have a chance to save their lives, so that they could get evacuated to the part of our country under our government control. They want to be in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So Mariupol is now destroyed and occupied. And I guess my question is, what's next?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Well, according to the mayor of that city, Ukrainian troops will reconquer that entire region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And he even gave me a timeline for that. He said that will happen before the end of the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Vadim Boishenko, whose own son is currently fighting on the front lines for that, said that Ukraine's victory will become a symbol that democracy can triumph over terror and tyranny, and that Mariupol itself will become a symbol once again, not a symbol of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, but one of hope.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: While the citizens of Mariupol are still alive, our Mariupol also lives.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We will definitely return to our Ukrainian Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It will happen this year, and we will rebuild a new, modern and heroic Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It will be the best city in the world, in a free and democratic world called Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So a defiant Vadim Boishenko there saying that he will continue to stay in touch with his residents that are inside Mariupol trying the best he can to help them until the day that they are reunited. All right Anneliese Borges our international correspondent there speaking thank you very much Russia has issued a conviction under its new fake news law brought in after the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: invasion of Ukraine Rylan the cube has more on that story a court in Russia has found that pure trim Milnikov has falsified Russian military documents as well as posting videos online which they claim were knowingly fake. Now according to local authorities and the investigative department Milnikov has been fined 1 million rubles and that's roughly 15,000 euros a staggering really large amount in Russia but he avoided the maximum fine of 15 years in prison. Now as you can see from this video, this has surfaced and it allegedly shows Milnikov giving a confession to local police officers, where he says, the information I posted about the Russian army is false. I admit that what I did was a mistake.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now, it's worth noting that this was put out by an anti-Kremlin account on Telegram, and they accuse the local authorities of giving a false confession. He was giving a confession under Juresh, which is kind of evident from his demeanour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Another case we've talked about on the programme before is that of Sasha Stochilenko, who was arrested in April for putting anti-war signs in the places of price tags in a local supermarket. One of them said, human life has no price. Another, don't be discouraged, we'll live in peacetime one day. And this is part of the wider attempt by the Kremlin to control the flow of information in the war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Milnikov's conviction was one of the first in Russia under this fake news law.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And, Stefan, it probably won't be the last, as there are many tens of people currently going through the Russian court system due to this law.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Rylan the Cube there, thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Authorities in northeast Brazil have confirmed at least 106 have died and 10 more missing after catastrophic rain caused widespread flooding and landslides

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: in Recife. The Brazilian army have been called in to help the fire department, as well as volunteers to search for survivors. President Jair Bolsonaro flew over the area, sit by the landslides and said the government was working to release financial aid to the affected communities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: At least 11 people have died and over 30 are missing after Hurricane Agatha swept through southern Mexico on Wednesday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The storm caused record-breaking landfall and severe flooding along the country's Pacific coast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Local authorities have ordered the closure of all schools and beaches in the region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Emergency storm shelters have since been established.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: West Ham defender Kurt Zuma has been ordered to serve 180 hours of community service after a video of him kicking and slapping his cat went viral.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: after a video of him kicking and slapping his cat went viral.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: London-based Zuma pleaded guilty last month to two counts under the Animal Welfare Act.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Zuma has also been banned from owning a cat for five years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And he's facing several fines, including a €300,000 fine from his own team and a €10,000 fine to cover court costs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The EU could soon release billions of euros in pandemic recovery funding to Poland's government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The move comes despite critics arguing the country has not done enough to change its judicial system, which was one of the conditions originally set to release the funds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Let's bring in our correspondent Maeve McMahon in Brussels who has more for us. Good evening Maeve and good to see you. So why the change of approach from the EU here?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening Stefan. We're still waiting for official confirmation from the European Commission.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The 27 commissioners have been locked behind closed doors all this afternoon and Paolo Gentilini, the EU commissioner in charge of the economy, is due to speak to the press a little bit later to confirm whether or not the commission has decided to trigger those funds. But we did hear a little bit earlier, or just last week, from the vice president of the European Commissioner, Dombrowski, that the commission did feel ready and stand ready to release those funds that were, of course, on hold for many, many months. Some 36 billion euros. Because many say the role that Poland has played hosting over 2 million Ukrainian refugees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But MEPs over in the European Parliament are furious, even though the announcement has not even been made. Because they believe that the EU would then lose its clout, lose all its leverage when putting pressure on the Polish government and the Prime Minister Mateusz Mariuszki when it comes to adhering to EU values and of course bringing about a more independent judiciary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: On another topic, Mejf, Denmark is holding a referendum on its opt-out for the EU's defence policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: What does that mean for Europe?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It is indeed. It's been a very busy day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: People have been voting over in Denmark on that opt-out that was brought about some 30 years ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It's worth pointing out that Denmark also has an opt-out regarding the euro.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Back in 2000, they were told they will never have to join at the euro but today people in denmark are voting on this defense and security issue and for more we can bring in now jacob kirkegaard he's not just an expert on all things related to the european union and defense and geopolitics but he's also a dane so jacob thank you so much for joining us on your own news first how's it looking how will the the outcome be, do you think? Well, if you believe the polls, it'll be an overwhelming vote yes for scrapping the defence opt-out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I mean, some polls are even suggesting two-thirds majority in favour, which by Danish referenda status is basically a landslide.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So what I think this shows is that, you know, unlike previous referendums, which have tended to be hijacked by the people opposing the vote and basically make it about everything else, sort of a general protest vote, etc.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That hasn't happened this time. It stayed much narrower.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But what about Brussels? What will this all mean for Brussels, for EU, the EU path towards more integration in the area of defence and security? Because many of our viewers are probably thinking just recently the neighbours, Sweden and Finland, asked for NATO membership. Well, I think, you know, Sweden and Finland joining NATO is a monumental decision for those two countries and will also dramatically alter the composition and posture of NATO itself. But whether or not, frankly, Denmark, which is a small country, joins the EU defence collaboration more actively is really a matter that I would go as far as to say predominantly affects Denmark itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's good for the rest of the EU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It's good for European integration.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But is it going to dramatically change European institutions?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: No, it's not. OK, so we should hold our breath on that point. Thank you so much, Jacob Kierkegaard there at Dane representing the German Marshall Fund. Thank you so much. All right. Maeve McMahon in Brussels, our correspondent there. Thank you so much for this update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's men's football team will play their first competitive fixture since Russia's

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: invasion of their country. Andrei Shevchenko's side take on Scotland in a World Cup qualifier playoff at a sold-out Hampton Park in Glasgow tonight. The game had been originally scheduled for March 24th, but was postponed due to the war. For more on this crucial qualifier let's bring in our sport correspondent Michael Kern. Good evening and this game it has a major significance on and off the field. What have both teams been saying ahead of tonight's game? Of course tonight's match of course there's a place in the World Cup later on this year riding upon it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: You've mentioned already that a massive night for Ukraine, their first major sporting fixture since the start of the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Emotions are going to be running high tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's my understanding there's going to be song sheets handed out to all the fans in the stadium so they can join in with the national anthem of Ukraine and support the nation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But of course, this is a football match, And I think you have to feel for Scotland slightly on this one, because I think the whole world is willing Ukraine to win this match this evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Some of their players have been speaking. Alexander Zinchenko, of course, the Manchester City player.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's been speaking to people from Ukraine that have been displaced, that they came to a training session the other week. And he basically said everyone's main dream is for this war to stop.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But when it comes to football, the team's dream is they want to go to the World Cup to give the incredible people of Ukraine the amazing emotions that it will be that they deserve so much at this moment in time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Of course, the Ukrainian home base players were given special dispensation to leave the country to train.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They've had a few friendlies in Germany, Italy and Croatia ahead of this game to get themselves prepared. But I alluded to Scotland, of course, because they want to get themselves to the World Cup as well. First time in 23 years they could go back-to-back tournaments after qualifying for Euro 2020. And Steve Clarke has said that they don't want to be one tournament wonder. So they're going to want to win tonight's game. I think there's going to be a lot of respect, a lot of support and a lot of love for Ukraine. But both these sides, of course, are going to want to win this one so they can get through to play Wales on Sunday. And of course, the winner of that game will be heading off to Qatar later on the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I can't let you go without asking you about that quarterfinal at Renault-Garros in Paris last night between Nadal and Djokovic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Walk us through this thriller that lasted way into the night.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, it was incredible, wasn't it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It was a match that started in May and finished in June.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Rafa Nadal previously had said, I want this early on in the day, I don't want to be playing this in the evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But what a spectacle it was, a four-set thriller.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The intensity of some of this tennis was another level.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We've been so blessed to see Rafa and, of course, Djokovic over the years going head-to-head.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And just the intensity was incredible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So Rafa's won this one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's through to the semifinal against Alexander Zarev now. But the standard of tennis was just incredible as they went head-to-head in this game.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And the temperatures were still 50 degrees at times as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So the temperature wasn't too cool either.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So an incredible match.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The audience and the viewers around the world thoroughly enjoyed it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But it just goes to prove what a master Nadal is on clay.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: You know, he's won the Roland Garros many, many times.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's a record holder when it comes to that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So he certainly set the crowd alight last night, and what a game it was for all to watch.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Absolutely. Michael Curran, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Across the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: UK, people are getting ready to celebrate the Queen's 70-year Jubilee. Along with an extended bank holiday, the country will host a series of special events to mark the historic moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Neil O'Reilly brings us more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Four days of pomp and pageantry.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The UK is marking 70 years of Queen Elizabeth's reign with celebrations and street parties across the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: At 96, the Queen remains as popular as ever, despite scandals affecting other members of the royal family.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Over the coming days, the public will show their appreciation in various events commemorating the Platinum Jubilee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: For some, it's the high point of a lifelong devotion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: My wishes for the Queen would be a happy, happy time together with her family.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It's very important to her family. She's got her dog, she's got her horses.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Obviously, she's still got her memories of Prince Philip, you wouldn't forget someone like that would you?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But I hope she has a sort of restful time because she worked so hard.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: A labour of love too for staff at the Legoland theme park where they've created their own depiction of the main event at Buckingham Palace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It's a far cry from how the start of her reign was celebrated in 1952, when a youthful Elizabeth ascended to the throne after the sudden death of her father.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But the sentiment remains as strong.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We'll leave you with a no comment from Saqqara in Egypt, where a cache of recently unearthed artifacts has gone on public display.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews tonight.
